text: On a similar note to a questions posed by <@U02ER51QSS0> on another channel - I’m encouraging our team to become more active on LinkedIn. Any tools, tips, advice, tactics etc. on how to make this part of our culture and help them get started? I don’t want to force it upon them so curious how I can build this more naturally :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: On a similar note to a questions posed by

on another channel - I’m encouraging our team to become more active on LinkedIn. Any tools, tips, advice, tactics etc. on how to make this part of our culture and help them get started? I don’t want to force it upon them so curious how I can build this more naturally

text:
Not sure if it’s doable for the whole team, but we picked the top 3 employees based on followers, connections, role, interest, etc. and wrote content by collaborating w/ them using the in-house social media team..

It helped them to experience the benefit of publishing content and they pretty much created the expectations among their connections…Then, our team slowly scaled back and they eventually learned/started to write themselves…

I’d suggest not to go for someone if you think they wouldn’t be able to find the time to write..it didn’t work for us.. We just used buffer for the experiment ..

elements.text:
Not sure if it’s doable for the whole team, but we picked the top 3 employees based on followers, connections, role, interest, etc. and wrote content by collaborating w/ them using the in-house social media team..

It helped them to experience the benefit of publishing content and they pretty much created the expectations among their connections…Then, our team slowly scaled back and they eventually learned/started to write themselves…

I’d suggest not to go for someone if you think they wouldn’t be able to find the time to write..it didn’t work for us.. We just used buffer for the experiment ..

text:
If you’re just getting started, it could help to organize a couple “LinkedIn jam” sessions with employees, where someone on your team provides a quick 10-15 min presentation about best practices and some prompts, and then you lead people through some brainstorms. The goal being to develop as many ideas/content-starters as possible while they’re in the session and have the opportunity to talk to an expert. Then use Slack or your team’s usual communication channels to keep up the encouragement, ask people to share best practices (ahem, you can also plant some change champions by asking specific individuals to weigh in!), and then highlighting folks who are workin git and getting good results.

All that said--it can be a very challenging thing to do if people aren’t interested themselves. At all points, underscore the “WIIFM” (what’s in it for me) in terms of sharing to help them get excited about the bigger picture.

The goal being to develop as many ideas/content-starters as possible while they’re in the session and have the opportunity to talk to an expert. Then use Slack or your team’s usual communication channels to keep up the encouragement, ask people to share best practices (ahem, you can also plant some change champions by asking specific individuals to weigh in!), and then highlighting folks who are workin git and getting good results.

All that said--it can be a very challenging thing to do if people aren’t interested themselves. At all points, underscore the “WIIFM” (what’s in it for me) in terms of sharing to help them get excited about the bigger picture.
